National Legal Environment Assessment and National Action Plan (output 1 and 2): Under this intervention the activities planned to be undertaken during the year focused on providing technical assistance to implement the LEA recommendations in the five countries. Specifically it was planned to organize multi stakeholder prioritization meetings, review specific legal/policy provisions and propose potential reforms/changes, identify parliamentarians to champion the priority issues and conduct strategy building sessions with parliamentarians and policy makers. In line with the above, all countries conducted prioritization exercise, identified specific legal provisions or policy areas and supported the legal/policy dialogue processes. Specific activities implemented across the different countries are summarised below.
In Angola the project supported the review process of the HIV Law 04/08 which operationalizes the National HIV Institute (National AIDS Commission). This exercise provided an opportunity to mainstream the relevant LEA recommendation and align the law to international/regional standards. The law has five chapters which includes provisions on protection of the the rights of vulnerable communities including key populations. The chapter also includes provisions on education, information, privacy, sexual and reproductive health, social security, labour, scientific advances, discrimination, key populations, specific rights of vulnerable populations and adolescents. This comprehensive bill has been presented to stakeholder and tabled to the NAC/ENLS for further review and adoption prior to being tabled to the Ministry of health and parliament. In Madagascar, the project provided technical support to the HIV and Law Commission and the NAC for the review of the National HIV Law 2005-040 of 2006 which provided the legal mandate for the National AIDS response including the role of the NAC. Ministry of Health and other Ministries, civil society organizations, etc. The law also includes provisions on protecting human rights and ensuring access to HIV services for all. Through the law revision process, a wide range of recommendations were made to the law review process for the NAC’s consideration. These include, among others, setting the age of consent for HIV testing and other services to fifteen years. Most importantly, however, it introduces a section on Key populations, and persons at risk, defined as female sex workers and their clients, men who have sex with men, people in prisons, injecting drug users, female partners of men who have sex with men, people having casual sex: sexually active young people aged 15-24 years in and out of school who practice unprotected sex. The recommendations made for the review have been presented to the HIV Law Commission and technical working group for further deliberations. In Zambia UNDP jointly with UNODC the national AIDS Commission and the Key Population Consortium which serves as the NSC for the LPP project, organized a High-Level policy dialogue meeting with selected law and policy makers focusing on barriers faced by Key Populations in accessing HIV services in Zambia. The overall objective of the dialogue which took place in August 2020 was to facilitate targeted high-level policy dialogue with individual Ministers and other policy making officials in the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Home Affairs, Ministry of Justice, and Ministry of Religious Affairs and National Guidance. Several consultations with key policy makers and key populations preceded the dialogue. During the consultation the Minsters critically reviewed the existing legal and policy environment in order to understand restrictive, inadequate, or punitive laws and provisions as well as identify gaps in enabling policies for sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) of Key Populations. Specific topics of discussion included, stigma, discrimination, and criminalisation of key populations, community engagement and participation, the importance of data to inform planning and budgeting processes; privacy, and confidentiality and gender-based violence. At the conclusion of the dialogue, the Ministers expressed their commitment to consider suspension of criminal sanctions on key populations for a given period to allow for public health programming and interventions to be developed and scaled; appreciated and acknowledged that an enabling environment, policy, and laws are critical for designing successful programme and reiterated that there is no official government policy which denies citizens the right to access comprehensive health care based on their sexual orientation or status in society. Going forward the meeting agreed to develop prosecutorial guidance on the appropriate use of the Anti-Gender-Based Violence Act and Penal Code provisions in relation to HIV, utilize the World Health Organization’s (WHO) guidelines for key populations when designing and improving programs, ensure patient privacy, confidentiality, and safety as high priority at healthcare facilities, and create a clinical environment of comfort, support, encouragement, and non-discrimination for key populations. In 2020, the project also continued the work started in 2019 with the NAC, the Zambia Association of Medical Doctors and the Zambia Intersex Society to develop Medical Management Protocol for Intersex Person. Once finalized, the protocol is expected to serve as a guideline to assist health care professionals in the provision of comprehensive interdisciplinary care to intersex persons and their family’s such as treatment, education, and psychosocial support to infants, children, adolescents, and adults born with disorders of sex development (DSDs) and to their families. Development of the protocol was preceded by a comprehensive situational analysis report themed ‘Being Intersex in Zambia: A review of International, Regional and National laws and policies’. The Protocol could not be finalised during the LPP project period but the process is taken forward through a process led by the NAC, Office of the Presidency and UNDP. In Zimbabwe the NSC identified several legislations that were in the reform pipeline either at ministerial or parliamentary level and monitored the reform process and progress including providing technical support to Parliamentarians. The legislations tabled for reform include Willful Transmission of HIV section 79 of the Criminal Code; Age of consent to Health service and SRHR; Termination of Pregnancy Act (TOP); Public Health Bill: punitive laws on infectious diseases, rights of KPs and other Vulnerable populations; Prisons Act Chapter 7:11; Criminalisation of Key Populations and Social Welfare Assistance. Review process of these bills is at different stages the most advanced being the Public Health Bill and the repeal of Willful Transmission of HIV which were both tabled in Parliament in 2021. In Zimbabwe the project also supported Trans Smart, and organization of young Transgender People to organize a two-day consultation with Senior Government Officials from the Ministry of Home Affairs on legal gender recognition for Transgender persons and gender affirmation services. Different stakeholders participated in the meeting including Zimbabwe Family Planning Council (ZNFPC), the Parliamentary Portfolio Committee on Health, religious leaders and Transgender led organizations (Trans Smart, TIRZ, and TREAT). The meeting raised several issues experienced by Transgender persons in Zimbabwe such as legal identification, access to services, incarceration and mental health and made a set of recommendations including high level engagement between the Transgender community and the Ministry of Home Affairs, the Immigration Department, Registrar General’s Department i.e., Minister and Principal Secretary level including the chief of immigration, chief Registrar; and Zimbabwe Republic Police. The meeting also agreed to hold similar dialogues and sensitization of political parties (the VFU and the ZRP leadership). Law, Policy and Strategy review undertaken in 5 countries (output 2) The main activities planned to be implemented under this intervention for 2020 were supporting young key populations engagement with parliamentarians and policy makers on priority areas for legal and policy reform and integration of the LEA recommendations in NSPs in Angola, Mozambique and Zambia. In line with the plan, the project organized dialogues and consultation events between young key populations and parliamentarians and policy makers as well as supporting participation of young key populations in the review and development of new national AIDS strategic plans. Accordingly in Angola, young key populations participated in the development of the NSP for the period 2020-2023. As a result of the active engagement of key populations and other stakeholders the new NSP fully integrated the reduction of stigma and discrimination including violence against key and vulnerable populations, particularly at points of provision of health services. The NSP also adapted strong human rights based strategies aiming at strengthening the legal and policy environment in line with the recommendations of the LEA. In Mozambique technical support was provided to the Mozambique National AIDS Commission for development of the 2021- 2025 National Strategic Plan for HIV, Treatment, Care and Support. The project supported different young key population groups including TransFormar, Lambda, Chada and other civil society organizations to undertake internal discussions on priority issues and facilitated inclusion of their voices through participation in multi stakeholder consultations, focus group discussions and review of draft documents. Technical support was also provided by the project to the National AIDS Council for the drafting of the Global Fund grant which is inclusive of the rights of key populations. The GFATM country application document was informed by the LEA report which was developed by the LPP project. Zambia conducted a review of the National HIV Strategic Plan in 2020 and young key populations were supported to participate in the process. Although many of the recommendations by the young key populations could not be incorporated into the final document as they were deemed sensitive and controversial, the young key populations developed the necessary skills and experience to engage with decision makers to ensure that they will continue to raise these issues during the implementation of the strategy. In Zimbabwe, UNDP in collaboration with the UN Joint Team supported members of parliament to undertake Public Hearings on the Legal Age of consent to Health services and SRHR. The public hearings provided an opportunity for Parliamentarians to listen and engage with young people and young key populations on the barriers they face when accessing services. The public hearings were carried out between October and November 2020. The public hearings were informed by the findings and recommendations of the LEA report on age of consent, stigma and discrimination and negative attitude of healthcare providers as barrier to equal access to health services for young people. The dialogue particularly focused on the need for lowering the age of consent to SRH Services from the current sixteen years (set in the National HIV Testing Guidelines of 2014 and the Public Health Act of 2018) as this has not lowered the rates of new HIV infections, unplanned pregnancies, and unsafe abortions amongst adolescents. The project also supported the engagement of young key populations to participate in petitioning the Parliament of Zimbabwe through the Speaker of Parliament, in March 2020 by over twenty youth led and youth focused organisation. The petition focused on the reduction of the age of consent in the Children’s Justice Act and Public Health Act of 2018 from 16 to 12 years.
Capacity strengthening activities for parliamentarians, policy makers, law enforcement and the judiciary undertaken in five countries (output 3): Under this intervention the main activity planned to be undertaken in 2020 was organizing the Annual meeting of the LEA NSCs at national and regional levels. Due to the travel and meeting restrictions that were put in place because of COVID-19, these regional and national NSC meetings were conducted virtually or in a hybrid format. A total of four webinars were organized by the project between 2020- 2021 with the national Steering Committees. These included three in-country-based meetings with the national steering committee members in Madagascar, Zambia, and Zimbabwe and one regional meeting conducted with the NSCs from the five countries.
The regional meeting of the NSCs was conducted in May 2020 with the overall objective of analyzing evolution of the project, including the NSCs themselves as structures and reviewing the status of implementation of the LEA findings and recommendations. Specifically, the meeting aimed at reviewing the activities, progress, and challenges including COVID-19 on the work of the NSCs, discuss and jointly reflect on some of the policy issues that are emerging from the country research led by HEARD and local research institutions, and explore strategies for sustainability of the project activities. At the conclusion of the meeting participants agreed on a set of actions to: • Ensure the sustainability of NSCs as a mechanism to undertake advocacy for law and policy reform, monitoring, and oversight to promote implementation, engaging with senior law and policy makers at country level (e.g., parliamentarians and members of the executive) and in the international arena (e.g., through Universal Periodic Review), as well as in promoting resource mobilization, • Build on successes shared at country-level, continuing to promote the ongoing use of the LEAs and Engagement Scans to effect change, • Follow up on key issues and priority actions arising, as above, and • Ensure that follow-up activities make efforts to include all young key populations, with specific efforts to ensure greater inclusion of young people who use drugs, young trans and intersex people, young people in prisons and closed settings Like the regional NSC meeting the national meetings of the NSC also focused on reviewing the status of the NSCs and the impact of COVID-19 on implementation of the LPP project activities.
The Zimbabwe the NSC meeting was conducted in May 2020. The overall objective of the meeting was strengthening capacities of the National Steering Committee and KP Forum members on the protection and promotion of human rights in the time of COVID-19. The meeting, which was attended by thirty three participants, provided a platform for young key populations to engage and deliberate with policy makers on strengthening policies and legal frameworks for key populations programming in the time of COVID-19 in various settings, create awareness on violations of human rights on key populations including restrictions imposed by governments, share global and international guidance on the protection of human rights during COVID-19; shared local experiences on current violations observed in the national response; discussed strategies to continue the LPP activities. The meeting highlighted that young key populations are disproportionately impacted by COVID 19 as there is lack of access to Covid 19 testing sites, disruption or discontinued access to ART due to lockdowns and travel restrictions, selective closing down of certain health facilities and prioritizing testing sites, lack of access to SRHR related services such as STI treatment, exclusion from social protection schemes provided to other citizens, and increased violence from family, community and law enforcement. To address these challenges, the meeting recommended development of a code of conduct or guideline for law enforcement officers, skills building sessions to increase vigilance and adoption of safety measures, inclusion of key populations in committees established by different authorities on COVID-19, putting in place complaints mechanisms and/or reporting platform for violations during COVID, and provision of free legal aid services for key populations through institutions like the Lawyers for human rights.
In Zambia the NSC meeting was held in June 2020 with over 22 participants from the NSC members and young key populations. The Meeting was jointly chaired by UNDP and the NAC Director. The meeting reflected on the overall impact of COVID-19 on the country, conducted in depth discussion on its effects on key populations and other vulnerable groups, shared lessons from the LPP implementation by the consortium partners over the four years, discussed strategies to sustain the LPP activities identified priority areas of action by different stakeholders, and outlined a plan to implement these strategies within the limitations and challenges that the COVID-19 pandemic will pose at national and sub national levels. Recommendations from the meeting included nomination of at least two young key populations for the National HIV technical committee coordinating review of the NAC Act and HIV policy, expediting the finalization of the intersex protocol to include gender affirming care, and rolling out the IPAC stigma and discrimination online training. The meeting made further recommendations to ensure sustainability of the LPP interventions, including strengthening Parliamentarians Portfolio committees on health to consider young key populations issues, strengthening partnerships with academia especially teaching hospitals for inclusive health workers training programmes, supporting increased representation of young key populations in SRH/HIV Committees; and creation of a data base for sharing of resources and materials developed by LPP and other similar projects in the country.
The NSC meeting in Madagascar was held in July 2020 with over twenty-four participants from the NSC members and young key populations. The Meeting was officially opened by the UNDP DRR and the NAC Director. Several members of the young key population community representing sex workers, young transgender and intersex people and young people who use drugs participated at the meeting. The webinar reviewed and prioritized advocacy activities for laws and policy reform in Madagascar, reviewed the implementation of the LEA recommendations and action plan including dissemination of the report, prioritized activities to be implemented before the end of the project and discussed sustainability strategies of the project supported activities beyond 2020. A presentation on the impact of COVID-19 on young key populations was made by Liberation an organization that advocates for LGBTQ people rights in Madagascar.
In addition to the national and regional NSC meetings, other country level activities on strengthening capacity of law enforcement were also undertaken. To this end, in Zambia a three-day meeting was organized with the Zambia Police Commission Law Enforcement training institute on supporting the of integration of key population issues in the training curriculum. This follows several meeting and discussions undertaken after the 2019 law enforcement regional training organized by the project in Pretoria. Based on the discussions, the Human rights and Health chapters of the Police Training Curriculum are identified as entry points for incorporating key populations issues within the police curricula. Sub themes for each were discussed and agreed. Content is under development, and this will be followed by a series of in-service training to pilot the curricula.
Assist SADC to strengthen regional frameworks to ensure they address HIV/SRH needs/rights of young key populations (output 5): In 2020 under this intervention it was planned to conduct the SADC regional KP strategy implementation progress review and conduct the annual meeting of the SADC NAC Directors meeting with UNAIDS, UNFPA and UNODC and the SADC Secretariat.
A progress review of the status of implementation of the regional key population strategy that was developed with support from the LPP project in 2017, was conducted covering all the sixteen SADC Member States. The report indicated that while significant results were achieved for several targets, it also showed that member States have not put in place a clear plan to support roll out of the strategy and measure the results. The report recommended targeted help for countries from the Secretariat and development partners in the adaptation and roll out of the strategy.
As in previous years, UNDP jointly with the SADC Secretariat, UNAIDS, UNFPA and UNODC organized the annual meeting of the SADC NAC Directors and technical professionals. Member States reported on the status of their HIV prevention, care and support programmes including HIV prevention among young key populations. The meeting approved the annual report which included the implementation status of the regional KP strategy which was presented to and approved by the Ministers of Health in November 2020.
Capacity strengthening activities for young SW, young LGBTI, young people in prison, young people who use drugs in HIV/SRH rights and access to justice in 5 countries (output 4): The activities planned for 2020 under this intervention included convening one joint caucus for all young key population groups and convening specific caucuses for each young key population group i.e., LGBT, SW, IDIUs and Inmates. While convening the separate caucus for the different young key population groups could not be undertaken with all groups due to several factors including the COVID-19 restrictions, limited organizational capacity of some young key population groups particularly young people who use drugs and lack of access to young people in prisons, several capacity building activities were implemented both with specific key population groups or the general young key population community. The capacity development activities were based on the tools developed by the project in previous years specifically the young key population advocacy guide
In Angola, a two-day virtual legal literacy training was held in November 2020. The training which was attended by young key populations, government officials and civil society organizations was officially opened by the State secretary from the Ministry of Justice. The meeting sought to build the legal literacy of young key populations, increase young key populations knowledge of laws and rights relevant to their sexual and reproductive health, and build their capacity to engage in international law and policy reform processes. The training covered an introduction to a wide range of international instruments such as Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR), International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), African Charter on Human and Peoples’ Rights (ACHPR), Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC), African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child (ACRWC), International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR), Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW), Protocol to the African Charter on Human and Peoples’ Rights on the Rights of Women in Africa (Maputo Protocol) participants also critically reviewed the Fundamental Rights section of the Angola constitution and the latest Angola UPR State Report. By the end the training young key populations gained skills on identifying rights violations and on application of the various international legal instruments to address those violations. Participants also reviewed the draft national HIV law that is currently under revision and provided inputs on the draft on the rights of young key populations, particularly in the area of protection from violence and access to services.

1. Technical support provided for the Multi stakeholder prioritization meetings to be undertaken in Zimbabwe and Zambia by May 2021 and by end of December 2021. 2. Finalise the review of National HIV Strategic Plans initiated in 2020 in Mozambique and Madagascar. 3. UNDP and AMSHeR jointly support YKPs to use digital platforms for advocacy including production of digital advocacy content. 4. Conduct annual face to face regional meeting of the NSCs or a series of online/virtual meetings over the course of the year to discuss country priorities. 5. Institutional support to partner organisations and young key populations to get access to internet connectivity and benefit from online activities during COVID-19 6. A regional consultant is recruited to undertake the KP strategy review, and a report is expected to be produced by end of the year. 8. The annual SADC meeting is expected to take place virtually in September 2021. 9. HEARD researchers and country teams continue with data generation, and finalise preliminary findings from research in Madagascar, Mozambique, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. 10. Submit several manuscripts produced by the HEARD Team to various journals for peer review and publication. 11. Develop briefs on the baselines in each country and publish on the web. 12. HEARD to conduct virtual core research team and local researcher’s meetings in 2021 as part of monitoring and providing oversight to data analysis. 13. Project monitoring and technical assistance missions done virtually following Covid 19 lockdown restrictions and increased cases. 14. The LPP project continued to provide technical and advisory support to project countries e to implement the LEA recommendations. Multi stakeholder prioritization meetings were organized in Angola and Zimbabwe to review specific legal/policy provisions and propose potential reforms/changes, identify parliamentarians to champion the priority issues and conduct strategy building sessions with parliamentarians and policy makers. In line with the above, the four countries conducted a prioritization exercise, identified specific legal provisions or policy areas and supported the legal/policy dialogue processes. Draft Baselines and strategic options papers were produced, these documents further informed the development f the annual workplans for these countries. Technical support was provided to Mozambique National AIDS Commission for the development of the 5th generation NSP. The NSP prioritizes key population and for the first time includes the need to address Transgender persons in policies and programmes. Madagascar reviewed its HIV law and introduced a section on Key populations including young key populations.
Relevant tools and guidance on the HIV/SRH-related needs and rights of each young key population developed (output 3): Under this intervention the main activity planned to be undertaken was training young key populations in the application of the civil society engagement scan. Following the plan, young key populations in all the five countries were provided with refresher trainings on the application of the Civil Society Engagement Scan. As a result of the trainings young key populations have developed the skills to engage with and provide inputs in important national reporting processes to international human rights mechanisms. In Mozambique young people were supported to produce a shadow report on the International Convention on Cultural and Political (ICCPR) which was submitted to the treaty body by TRANS Formar a Transgender movement of Mozambique, established by young transgender persons. These organization are one of the young key population groups that received continuous capacity building trainings through the LPP project. The organizations seek to advocate and promote inclusion of sexual and gender identity especially transgender rights, in socio-economic, political, and cultural policy development agenda; advocate for legal gender recognition in law; eliminate associated stigma and discrimination and create awareness on transgender issues including access to comprehensive health care. The report published on the ICCPR Committee website highlights five key areas i.e. violence and arbitrary arrests of key populations, discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, recognition of gender identity, access to lifesaving medical treatment for young people and implementation of comprehensive sexuality education. In Zimbabwe young key populations were provided training and technical support on the preparation of the Universal Periodic Review shadow report to the human rights mechanisms and follow up to previous recommendations. In 2021 the Government of Zimbabwe was due for the third cycle reporting to the 40th session of the Human Rights Commission (HRC) Universal Periodic Review (UPR) Working Group meeting scheduled for Jan/Feb 2022. During a two-day meeting, young key populations received technical support from the project to produce the first young key population focused shadow report to the Human Rights committee. The report which was submitted to the committee by Trans and Intersex Rising Zimbabwe (TIRZ) covered criminalization of HIV transmission and its impact on young key populations, criminalization of consensual sex between adult men, stigma, discrimination and violence, gender markers, and education and information on sexual and reproductive health services. Submission of the UPR shadow report presented an opportunity for young key populations to practically use the advocacy skills gained over the years through the LPP project and they will continue to monitor the process through their organizations. Capacity strengthening activities for young SW, young LGBTI, young people in prison, young people who use drugs in HIV/SRH rights and access to justice in 5 countries (output 4) In Zambia a three-day capacity strengthening meeting for Zambia’s young key population on digital media was held in May 2021. The training aimed at building journalistic skills, optimizing the use of digital technological platforms in creating and curating content for sexual reproductive health and human rights advocacy, and reporting on issues affecting young key population’s access to services. The training was attended by twenty young people covered topics such as article development and writing, usage of digital technology (social media platforms, virtual rooms, podcasts), photography and video editing. The lessons were delivered through peer-to-peer learning utilizing the skills that exists within the young key population community. The training enabled young key populations to create their own narrative, content and purposefully occupy digital and virtual spaces to ensure presence and amplify their voices. To sustain young voices in the policy space and promote active participation on the use of digital technology, digital equipment was provided for young key population organizations (Intersex Society of Zambia (ISSZ), Decisive Minds (DM), The Lotus Identity (TLI), Umotto Centre of Culture) involved in the design and implementation of the training. This equipment will be used for continuous content creation as well as skill development by the organizations. Some of the stories generated in this training will be published on the UNDP website.
In Zimbabwe young key populations organized a series of capacity building sessions for Lesbians, Bisexual, and Queer (LBQ) persons, LGBTI sector capacity strengthening on strategic litigation and Young Sex-Workers Academy. All the capacity building events were led by GALZ with support from the project. The meetings were held in four provinces (Bulawayo, Masvingo, Mutare and Harare) and reached over seventy young people. The LBQ sensitization workshops focused on strengthening capacity of the community stakeholders and organizations on Sexual Orientation Gender Identity and Expression (SOGIE) concepts (stereotyping, boxes, and binaries, lived realities) of LGBTIQ persons and exclusion of LBQT women in the broader gender equality discourse. Participants were drawn from the wider women’s movement and civil society organizations working on gender equality. At the conclusion of the meeting, participants made several recommendations to strengthen the integration of LBQ issues in the relevant national plans and strategies. These include: • increased awareness raising campaigns and dissemination of SOGIE information to communities and CSOs, • inclusion of SOGIE in comprehensive sexuality education, • integration of LGBTI rights in the human rights advocacy agenda of civil society organizations. • increased advocacy on adoption of gender markers for trans persons. • sensitizations of parents, friends, allies, influencers, and traditional leaders of the LBQ on SOGIE, and • bottom-up advocacy for the recognition of the LBQ community.
Zimbabwe also conducted a strategic litigation workshop aimed at strengthening capacities of the LGBTIQ+ community on the use of ‘litigation’ as a strategy for law and policy reform. The workshop provided an opportunity to identify potential litigants among LGTBIQ+ stakeholders and harmonize interventions implemented by the different partners. The meeting highlighted that legislature in Zimbabwe has been evading amending the law to make clear provisions that provide for the recognition of the rights of the LGBTIQ persons. It also highlighted that there are no policies that allow for the transgender and the intersex people to change their gender markers on their identity documents. In order to address these and other challenges face by Transgender people, participants of the meeting recognized the need to review the constitution of 2013 to ensure rights are interpreted in a manner that allows LGBTI people to enjoy protection as any human being in Zimbabwe without being attacked or arrested due to their sexual identity. The meeting also explored cases for litigation and provided a comparative analysis of the Botswana, Angola, and Kenya Jurisprudence. The participants agreed on the importance of taking up strategic litigation as an advocacy tool towards the end of rights violations and to address the awareness gaps on arguments that the courts and the State use to deny LGBTI rights. The meeting also called upon the LGBTI sector and defenders, champions, and allies to be on the alert and always on the lookout for opportunities that arise, either to ensure rights are protected and for those violated there is redress. The participants also noted the potential backlash that could arise from litigation and emphasized the need to assess the legal, political, and social environment before initiating litigation cases.
The Young Sex-Workers academy brought together young sex workers in their diversity to discuss empowerment of sex workers, increasing their understanding of SRHR and policy advocacy opportunities, safety and security, advocacy and human rights and barriers to health care services.
National Mechanism for community monitoring to feed into policy and service provision established (output 4): The two main activities planned under this intervention were organizing a regional meeting on advocacy for young key populations and supporting participation of young key populations at regional events. While both activities were implemented successfully, the project also supported several other activities towards strengthening national mechanism for community monitoring to include policy development and service provision. The main event organized in the reporting period was the Regional Youth Training Institute that brought together more than sixty young people from the five project countries. The event was organized by UNDP in close collaboration with HEARD and national key population organizations including GALZ of Zimbabwe, TransFormar of Mozambique, Trans Bantu of Zambia ASSOFRAMA and Liberation of Madagascar and IRIS of Angola. Resource people from several organizations including FrontlineAids. The overall objective of the Institute was to take stock of progress made in achieving young key populations empowerment in SRHR advocacy, consolidate and scale up their skills in view of the current realities. More specifically, the meeting aimed at reviewing progress and challenges in engagement of young key populations in policy advocacy at national and regional levels through sharing stories and exchanging experiences and skills building on digital transition. The meeting also assessed how the tools produced by the project i.e., the Civil Society Engagement Scan and the young key populations Advocacy Guide have been operationalized in the past two years and develop strategies for better use of tools and data for better advocacy outcomes in each country and explored potential initiatives for sustainability of young key populationss engagement beyond the current phase of the LPP project. The three days meeting was held in a hybrid format. Participants from Angola, Mozambique, Zambia, and Zimbabwe convened in a physical venue secured by UNDP with full compliance with environmental, Covid-19 hygiene and social distancing protocols. Delegates from Madagascar attended virtually and were directed to break-away rooms to deliver on their group work. Presentations were made via Zoom and in person break-away group works were conducted in the four countries except for Madagascar where Covid-19 did not allow in-person gathering. Simultaneous interpretation was provided and translated materials were shared with participants in Portuguese, French, and English.
Following rich discussion, experience sharing and skills building, the Institute culminated the development of a Communique on issues affecting equitable access to HIV prevention and SRH of young key populations in the region. The Communique highlighted, amongst other issues, the growing prevalence of HIV infections and AIDS-related deaths amongst key populations, poor sexual and reproductive health, and rights (SRHR) outcomes among key populations and marginalized communities, legislative, policy and social frameworks that continue to deny legal gender recognition perpetuate violence, stigma, discrimination and exclude young key population especially transgender people. The Communique also indicated the disproportionate impact of Covid-19 on young key populations, which has increased economic vulnerability and unemployment amongst young people and exacerbated mental health crisis. The document emphasized the need to re-think a development pattern that does not recognize interlocking systems of oppression, that is not people-centered or youth-inclusive, that de-prioritizes human rights. The Communique was officially submitted by GALZ on behalf of the participants to the SADC Secretariat for the attention of the Ministers of Youth and Ministers of Health at regional level and was forwarded to the Health Ministries in the various countries. It was also disseminated through social media (Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram) for wider circulation and reach to the key population community, allies, and champions.
As in previous years, the project continued supporting participation of young key populations in regional platforms. Accordingly, more than twenty young key populations from the five project countries participated in the annual NAC Directors meeting that took place in September 2020. Increased number of participations was made possible in 2020 due to the hybrid nature of the meeting which whereby country level participants had the opportunity to attend physically or virtually while regional level participants attended the meeting virtually.
Assist SADC to strengthen regional frameworks to ensure they address HIV/SRH needs/rights of young key populations (output 5)
In 2021 under the LPP continued to support the planned SADC regional KP strategy implementation progress review and conduct the annual meeting of the SADC NAC Directors meeting in collaboration with UNAIDS, UNFPA and UNODC and the SADC Secretariat. The focus for the 2021 regional meeting was on rolling out of the Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026, and the UN Political Declaration’s 2025 Commitments in SADC Region. Propose a roadmap for rolling out the Global AIDS Strategy and Political Declaration in the SADC Region. Facilitate commitment to align the new strategy and targets with the NSPs; Consider and discuss draft annual HIV/AIDS report, draft HIV M&E Indicator Framework, and other important documents to be presented during the upcoming Joint meeting of SADC Ministers of Health and Ministers Responsible for HIV and AIDS. Some countries joined completely virtually while others adopted the hybrid approach depending on the Covid numbers in the different countries.
Baseline Studies and mid-term review. (output 6) Baseline studies for the five countries were completed and reported in 2019. In 2021 HEARD continued to design and conduct research in the five countries based on the findings and recommendations of the baseline studies. 2.2.5 Operational research (output 6) HEARD’s operational research around the following themes of gender-based violence, reproductive health and rights, mental health, the economies of transactional sex, prison health, social stigma, community interaction, and the functionality of the law for minority groups experienced disruptions due to the global COVID pandemic and related restrictions in movement and stay-at-home policies in the five project countries. Around mid-March institutional ethics bodies instructed the teams to stop in-person data collection with immediate effect, which negatively impacted on the workplans and research outputs in each country and with high uncertainty as to when data collection would be resumed. Between March and October 2020, teams focused on the analysis of collected data and the development of research reports and publications. They switched to virtual meetings to discuss their research activities and plan for the necessary adjustments. Research protocol amendments and SOPs were prepared and submitted to ethics bodies to request the approval of telephonic interviews with research participants, after having piloted this approach in Zambia. In the fourth quarter of 2020, HEARD and its local partners were able to resume the data collection with activities extending into 2021 based on a no-cost extension agreement with UNDP and the funder. The analyses of research data continued also after the no-cost extension period.
Madagascar HEARD continued the collaboration with colleagues from the University of Antananarivo to collect data within prisons and youth detention centers on the SRHR of young people in these institutions. The research was carried out through semi-directive interviews with a total of 158 young detainees, as well as prison directors and medical staff. The research produced new data on a previously understudied population of young people who experience serious challenges to their SRHR. Results from the study were presented to stakeholders including the Ministry of Justice and a report published and disseminated.
Research findings The research revealed the intersection of factors of vulnerability to poor SRHR for young people in prison based on their age, and social class/wealth. Young people with no family support and no economic resources are particularly at risk of poor SRH. A lack of dedicated spaces and services for young people in prisons contributes their vulnerabilities to poor SRH. Although there is sporadic HIV testing in all prisons, this is not regular or systematic and there is a general lack of information and education on HIV and other SRH issues. Moreover, a denial of the possibility of sexual relations within prison and between prisoners means that prevention programmes, such as the distribution of condoms, are not undertaken. Young women face specific difficulties, with restricted access to menstrual hygiene products, and to family planning or ante-natal care. In one establishment, we found that young women regularly gave birth in prison with no specialized medical care. Research outputs • Freedman, J, Rakotoarindrasata, M., and JdD Randrianasolorivo (2021). Analysing the economies of transactional sex amongst young people: Case study of Madagascar. World Development 138: 105289. • Freedman, J., Rakotoarindrasata, M., & de Dieu Randrianasolorivo, J. (2020a). Remise en Cause des Frontières supposées entre travail du sex et sex transactionnel à Madagascar - Cas deNosy Be. Paris: Institut du Genre en Géopolitique. • Freedman, J., Rakatoarindrasata, M. & Randraianasolorivo JdD (2020). Santé sexuelle et reproductive chez les jeunes ‘populations clés’ à Madagascar. Durban: HEARD • Freedman, J., Rakotoarindrasata, M. et Randrianasolorivo, JdD (2021). Étude sur la santé sexuelle et reproductive des jeunes détenu.e.s à Madagascar. Durban: HEARD.
Mozambique HEARD and UEM engaged with young LGBTI and sex workers directly in the third and last phase of the operational research in Mozambique. This phase sought to deepen the findings from the previous phases during which legal experts and community leaders were interviewed on issues of the law, social norms with regards to homosexuality, gender diversity and sex work, and the functionality of the current legal framework in protecting LGBTI individuals and sex workers. Semi-structured and biographical narrative interviews as well as focus group discussions were used to explore the personal experiences of approx. 200 young people in Nampula, Quelimane and Maputo with the views, attitudes, and actions of others regarding their sexual orientation, gender identity or involvement in sex work activities and to understand their knowledge of the law and the barriers they face in exercising their rights. Data collection in the last study site was finalized in April 2021. The team continued to work on the analysis of data beyond the closure date of the project and expects to finalize this before the end of October. In-country dissemination of the research findings as well as different research publications are in preparation.
Preliminary research findings Preliminary analysis of the data shows that many of the young people had experiences with discrimination and exclusion for being ‘different’ or for engaging in ‘immoral sexual behavior’. There was a strong economic determinant which inhibited disclosure and openness in the lives of young LGBT. Family situations of economic dependency made this often impossible, and interviews with those who had disclosed or had been found out, revealed the economic and social repercussions and within an environment with limited opportunities for young people (YWSS) to be self-supporting. Preliminary analysis of the family histories of young women selling sex suggested that the majority had either suffered the early loss of a parent and/or had migrated to the city to stay with a relative. Introductions into sex work occurred at a young age, and against a considerable risk (e.g., being uninformed about contraceptive methods, about the law on sex work and protection). Self-stigma emerged particularly from the interviews with the young women selling sex who aspired a ‘decent’ job after completing their studies. The internalization of religious and socio-cultural values around the sacredness of female sexuality led some to believe their activities were illegal whilst this is not the case. One other important aspect, which emerged from the data, was the lack of trust in the police and the justice system, which meant many of the participants had not acted against the perpetrators of discriminatory and violent acts. While this still needs further analysis, it points at (one of) the limitations of the law reforms, which were bereft of public debate and a government-led strategy to promote inclusion, largely leaving the structural and intermediary determinants which expose these young people to a poorer sexual and reproductive health unaddressed. Research outputs • Aantjes, C.J., Munguambe, K., Muchanga, V., Capurchande, R. and Poku, N.K. (2021). Why Doesnt the Decriminalisation of Same-Sex Sexuality and Sex Work Ensure Rights? The Legality and Social Acceptance of Transgressive Sexualities in Urban Mozambique. Sexuality Research and Social Policy, 1-16. • Munguambe, K., Capurchande, R., Muchanga, V., and Aantjes, C.J. (2020). Societal views on LGBTI people and sex workers in three cities in Mozambique. Durban: HEARD. • Lay summary in English and Portuguese (2021). Opinions and interactions with community members who are ‘different’: a look into sex workers and gay people in the context of changing laws. • Research snapshot in English and Portuguese (2021). Young key populations study in Mozambique.
Zambia In early 2020, HEARD implemented a second piece of research in Zambia for the purpose of building comparative research linked to that conducted in 2019 in Zimbabwe, thereby deepening the evidence base for Southern Africa, more broadly. This research in Zambia aimed to explore the determinants and outcomes of unintended pregnancies amongst young women who sell sex (16-24 years old) at the socio-economic and environmental level, behavioral level, and service level in Zambia, with a view to informing policy and practice to better support the reproductive health of young women who sell sex. We aimed to compare the findings between the two country contexts to better understand some of the common structural and intersectional vulnerabilities to poor SRH experienced by YWSS in the region.
The COVID pandemic began at the same time as the fieldwork training was being conducted in February 2020 and the first lockdown in Zambia meant the research was unavoidably delayed. In 2020, our planned focus group discussions were no longer possible, but we conducted a hybrid of telephonic and face to face in depth interviews depending on the COVID situation at the time. In total, we carried out 66 in depth interviews and 3 FGDs with young women who self-identified as selling sex in Lusaka and Chipata. Lusaka is the capital and largest city of Zambia and Chipata is the administrative center of the Eastern Province of Zambia and borders Malawi. In Lusaka, sex workers were initially recruited via sex worker organizations, thereafter further sex workers were recruited through snowballing sampling techniques. In the first wave of recruitment, sex workers from 3 communities in Lusaka Province were initially recruited and in the second recruitment wave, sex workers living in 4 different communities were recruited. In Chipata, sex workers were recruited through sex worker organizations, thereafter snowballing sampling was used. In the second wave of recruitment in Chipata, sex workers were also recruited from the street-based venues or from bars. The fieldwork was completed in May 2021 and data analysis is now underway. Research outputs • Armstrong, R., Silumbwe, A. and Zulu, J.M. (2020). Mental health, coping and resilience among young men who have sex with men in Zambia. Culture, Health & Sexuality, 1-15. • Zulu, J.M. & Armstrong, R (2020). Exploring the social determinants of mental health for young adult men-having-sex-with-men in Zambia: Findings from a mixed-methods study. Durban: HEARD.
Zimbabwe HEARD conducted a third phase of research in 2020 to deepen understanding of the dynamics of gender-based violence amongst YWSS as a key cross cutting SRHR issue which emerged as an area requiring further exploration in the 2019 fieldwork. This research sought to explore the different types of violence experienced by YWSS and the spectrum of determinants and consequences, in particular the intersectional forms of risk and vulnerability linked to the different forms and manifestations of gender-based violence, and the types of support sought and provided following experiences of violence. We carried out a further 48 in depth interviews and 16 FGDs with young women who self-identified as selling sex in Harare and Bulawayo, as well as eight key informant interviews. Harare is the capital and most populous city in north-eastern Zimbabwe in the countrys Mashonaland region. Bulawayo is the second largest city in the western part of Zimbabwe and the largest city in the countrys Matabeleland. In Harare, Young women who self-identified as selling sex were recruited from 14 different locations both within and as far as 56km outside the city. In Bulawayo, participants were recruited from the city center and the surrounding peri-urban areas up to 30km from the city center. Young women were initially recruited from the street where they were soliciting for clients, from bars, and/or lodges. We followed a snowball sampling method. We asked participants who we had already recruited, who lived in one area but did not work there, to assist with recruitment of other young women who worked in these areas. In this way, we sought to avoid competition between participants and inclusion of friends as well as expanded our recruitment sites. Interviews were conducted in the local languages (Shona in Harare and Ndebele in Bulawayo) and translated and transcribed into English. The fieldwork was completed in February 2021 and data analysis is now underway.
Research findings Preliminary findings suggest that YWSS experience violence on a continuum where the legal context, poverty, childhood trauma, social stigma, and gender-based violence as an occupational consequence interact and compound the negative impacts on mental health. Violence interventions for sex workers tend to focus on violence in their immediate occupational context and amongst older, rather than younger, people who sell sex and the relationship between gender-based violence and other interconnected and mutually reinforcing systems of oppression, power, and inequity is frequently overlooked. There is need to position YWSS’s experiences of gender-based violence within a focused historical, socio-economic, and political context as analysis continues. Research outputs • Crankshaw, T.L., Chareka, S., Zambezi, P. and Poku, N.K. (2021). Age Matters: Determinants of sexual and reproductive health vulnerabilities amongst young women who sell sex (16–24 years) in Zimbabwe. Social Science & Medicine, 270, 1-9. • Chareka, S., Crankshaw, TL., and Zambezi, P. (2021). Economic and social dimensions influencing safety of induced abortions amongst young women who sell sex in Zimbabwe. Sexual and Reproductive Health Matters 29, no. 1 (2021): 1881209. • Crankshaw, TL, Zambezi, P and Chareka, S. (2021). Reproductive Health and Rights Challenges of Young Women who Sell Sex (16-24 years) in Zimbabwe. Durban: HEARD
Angola As with the other countries, operational research activities in Angola faced delays due to the COVID situation. However, serious frictions within the local team had also built up and the multiple telephonic interventions by the core team could not prevent an eventual deadlock situation in the implementation of research deliverables in Angola in quarter 4 of 2020. A decision was made not to renew the contract with this local team until June 2021, as it was done in other project countries. Due to the continued travel restrictions and a pending second wave of infections in the region, and considering the project’s end in June 2021, HEARD focused the attention on producing an extensive baseline report and closed the operational research arm.
The baseline found there is very little research on the specific circumstances that shape the risks and vulnerabilities of young key populations in Angola; that is the social and economic determinants of their health and welfare and of their needs and challenges with regard HIV/SRH and rights. Bio-medical surveys have indicated poor health status and outcomes, in terms of HIV prevalence and, to some extent, prevalence of other sexually transmitted illnesses, however, there are a few Angolan studies which have explored the social and economic factors underlying these poorer health outcomes, such as gender inequality, poverty, lack of education and/or employment. While the government acknowledges sex workers, men who have sex with men, people who inject drugs and prisoners as key populations, it places an emphasis, in its health plans and programmes, on ‘priority’ populations (uniformed services, truck drivers and miners), and ‘vulnerable’ populations (pregnant women and adolescents, amongst other). Interviews with stakeholders revealed that the concept of key populations has received increased attention over the past few years in Angola but mostly because of the advocacy and research foci in donor-driven programmes, such as USAID and UNAIDS. Representatives of donor-supported key population organizations expressed some ambivalence with the bio-medical, specifically HIV risk, focus in donor agency and government use of the KP concept and would welcome the adoption of the health rights component of the WHO definition of key population as a more solid basis for lobbying for social inclusion and against societal discrimination and stigma of young key populations. Research outputs • Quinlan, T. (2020). Angola Baseline report on young key populations and sexual and reproductive health and rights. Durban: HEARD. 2.2.6 Dissemination of Research Findings and Comparative analyses (output 6) In 2020, the HEARD core research team designed a comparative cross-country study on the health, economic and social impacts of the COVID-19 national responses on sex workers of all genders. The unprecedented scale of this health crisis provided the research component in the LPP project with a unique opportunity to deepen its investigation on the access of young key populations to SRHR services in times of crises and the vulnerabilities that arise because of restrictions under the national COVID responses. The focus on sex workers followed from the intersectionalities between the different young key population groups that became apparent from HEARD’s ongoing operational research in this project. Intersectionalities include but are not limited to sexual orientation, gender identity, age, and social class within the group of sex workers. This study was planned for and implemented during the no-cost extension period in Madagascar, Mozambique, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. At the time of reporting on the 2020-2021 period, data collection in Madagascar had recently been completed and the teams in Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe had completed fieldwork and were currently analysing the interview transcripts. Preliminary findings suggest that all groups of young people selling sex had predispositional vulnerability to experiencing increased economic and social hardship over the first two COVID waves. However, the experience of vulnerability was unequally distributed and the differing geopolitical and socio-economic positions, and gendered and age-related determinants, both within and between the groups of participants, played a key role in determining the extent and type of vulnerabilities experienced. In 2021, the core research team also prepared and submitted manuscript, presenting country data from Madagascar, Mozambique, Zambia, and Zimbabwe, for a special journal issue around sex work and the law in the International Journal of Gender, Sexuality, and the Law. In the same year, a book chapter was published by members of the core research team with the title Young Key Populations in Southern Africa: an analysis of the social determinants of HIV risk and barriers to SRH services in the book Preventing HIV Among Young People in Southern and Eastern Africa: Emerging Evidence and Intervention Strategies, by editors Govender, K. and Poku, N.K. and published by Routledge. Across 2020 and 2021, HEARD disseminated findings on different platforms and in different formats, as they became available. The LPP project page on HEARD’s website as well as HEARD’s Facebook page were used to upload resources and draw attention to the research findings. Detailed country research reports were prepared and made available on the HEARD website and shared with project partners, the funder and country stakeholders. At least one scientific publication per country was published open access to increase the access and visibility of the research in the region. Due to COVID-19 restrictions, the dissemination of findings to study participants and country stakeholders largely relied on digital means of communication and exchange with the exception of Madagascar where, under stringent precautions, stakeholders were able to meet physically. HEARD’s local research partner, Mina Rakotoarindrasata and Jean de Dieu Randrianasolorivo, facilitated two meetings in Antananarivo to present and discuss the SRH study among young people in- and out of school and the research in prisons and correctional services. Stakeholders at these meetings included the Ministries of Health, Youth, Population, Social protection and Gender Promotion, the National Council for the Fight against HIV and AIDS, civil society organisations as well as the academic community. In June 2021, HEARD presented the country findings as well as the findings from comparative pieces at a hybrid regional NSC meeting. During this presentation, HEARD focused on the key issues that emerged from the project’s research component and the subsequent implications of these findings for existing country laws, policies and programmes targeted at young key populations. Participants showed an interest and keen engagement during the time that was allocated for questions and discussion with the researchers, which included both core and local research team members. In May 2021, HEARD presented at the 3-day Regional Youth Leadership Institute, whereby direct inputs were asked on a research product which HEARD had specifically designed to target young people in the region and draw their attention to the research findings. The product – called a research snapshot - was subsequently refined, and snapshots were prepared and disseminated on the country studies in Zambia and Mozambique. HEARD also developed two clips in which the approach and impact of young people’s involvement in two country studies are showcased. The media clips feature the change stories which include the voices of the local investigators and the student/peer researchers in the country studies of Zambia and Madagascar. To make the media more widely accessible and attracting young people in the region, they were posted on the HEARD Facebook page, in addition to the HEARD website (see weblinks below). Zambia https://www.heard.org.za/news-post/peer-to-peer-research-on-mental-health/ Madagascar https://www.heard.org.za/news-post/madagasca-change-story/ In Mozambique, the team prepared and disseminated lay summaries of the research findings in Portuguese through the municipality and other gatekeeper structures within the three study sites, instead of organising community gatherings in view of the imposed restrictions on such events. 2.3 Local capacity building As in previous years the project continued to contribute to local capacity building in several ways. Some examples include the media training undertaken in Zambia with local civil society organizations and key population groups. The media training which was mainly designed, delivered, and reported by experts from the key population community not only transferred skills to the participants but also contributed to the creation of sustainable capacity in producing and disseminating communication products by the key population community. In Zimbabwe and Mozambique key civil society organizations and key population groups received technical support to develop shadow reports on their country’s respective country reports to the Universal Periodic Review and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The various operational and thematic research conducted by HEARD continue to build capacity of local academic institutions across the project countries as well as local consulting firms and organizations that support the research in data collection, analysis, report writing and dissemination. 2.4 Alignment with national priorities All activities of the project are aligned with national priorities as the design, implementation and monitoring is informed by the appropriate national plans particularly the national strategic plans for AIDS. Accordingly, the policy advocacy activities in the different countries follow the priorities identified in the national plans such as revision of the HIV laws in Angola and Madagascar and the Public Health Act review in Zimbabwe. Using these national priorities as entry points the project provided technical assistance to young key populations to participate in the process and ensure inclusion of their voices and issues in the documents. The project also directly supported the government bodies responsible for these processes like the National AIDS Councils in Angola and Madagascar and the Health Portfolio Committee of the Parliament of Zimbabwe. In Mozambique, the project provided technical support to the development of the fifth ‘Plano Estratégico Nacional de Resposta ao HIV e SIDA- (PEN 5) as well as the Country’s proposal to the Global Fund for AIDS, TB and Malaria (GFATM). 2.5 Innovation Due to the effects of COVID-19 in restricting travel and meetings throughout 2020 and 2021, majority of the project activities were implemented through online methods including meetings, data collection, information exchange and dissemination. COVID-19, however, disproportionately affected key population groups who had limited access to the internet, lack the necessary material and knowhow to effectively engage with and benefit from the online activities and events. To close this gap the project adopted some innovative approaches such as the creation of information and communication hubs in key population organizations by providing them with materials and internet connectivity. These hubs enabled young key populations to have safe and reliable access to online content and facilitated their participation in the project activities. 2.6 Sustainability The project design identified four main sustainability strategies to ensure continuity and effectiveness of the interventions. These include putting in place inclusive, participatory, and multi-sectoral national structures to guide the design and implementation of activities, building on and integrating the interventions in national priorities and existing processes, continued focus on capacity development of communities and other stakeholders, and encouraging linking, sharing, and learning across countries. Accordingly, as in previous years, in the reporting period the project continued to work with the National Steering Committees in the various countries. However, this process has been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic which limited travel and physical meetings. This meant that for the first the time since the start of the project the regional meeting of the National Steering Committees could not be held physically and had to be held virtually. At national level, the work of the NSCs in Mozambique and Madagascar was affected by structural changes in the lead organizations. In terms of integration to national priorities, the project continued to align with national priorities as described in section 2.4. Capacity development continues to be done as described in various sections above and learning and linking at national level is supported through the NSC meetings, the Leadership Institute and various communication products developed by the project. Sustainability of the project interventions also requires continued resource mobilization. To this end UNDP developed a new project named the Southern African Young Key Populations Initiative. The project which is informed by the lessons learnt from the LPP, will contribute to sustaining the results of the project at regional and national levels.
